titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to C. L. Hinkle, May 14, 1902
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Letter and envelope. Curtis L. Hinkle was clerk of the Wyoming State Land Board in Cheyenne and friend to WFC. "Mr. Hawks" and "Nelson" are currently unidentified. WFC tried to establish The Elks' National Home in Cody, Wyoming. DeForest Richards (1846-1903) was likely the governor to whom WFC sent regards, but he died in office two weeks before this letter was written (April 28). BBWW performed in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, May 12-17, 1902.

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to C. L. Hinkle

div1.p: Yours 9th to hand Mr. Hawks2 & Nelson— are now at Cody looking the Cody- and Salsbury Canal over— They will be in Cheyenne soon They will ask for water for placer mining. as well as for irrigation and it will be for the best interest of the state to be liberal as the building of this expensive canal means much—
Yes Cody is still in line for the Elks Home.3 And I trust that the Wyo Elks will work for it.
With very kindest regards to the Govrnor4 and others.

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Philadelphia from May 12 to May 17, 1902.

Note 2: "Hawks" might be Frank Lee Houx (1854-1941), who was elected the first mayor of Cody, Wyoming, in 1901. Houx later served as Wyoming secretary of state from 1911 to 1919, and was acting governor from February 1917 to January 1919. Houx' biography in the Wyoming Historical Blue Book (published 1943) states that he had been involved in irrigation projects near the town of Cody.

Note 3: The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, of which William F. Cody was a member, had recently decided to establish a home for elderly and infirm members. Cody attempted to use his influence to induce the Elks to build their retirement home near "his" town of Cody, Wyoming, but was ultimately unsuccessful. The Elks National Home opened in Bedford, Virginia, in 1903.
Note 4: DeForest Richards (1846-1903) was then the governor of Wyoming.
